channel.title: Math algebra shit
channel.description: Explain why the expressions 2 + 4n and 6 + 4 (n-1) can both be used to find the perimeter of a string of hexagons " n" is the variable that u use to multiply the term number of the string of hexagons like 1 string of hexagons is 6 and 2 strings of hexagons is 10 and 3 strings of hexagons is 14 so on so forth

item.title: Math algebra shit
item.dc:creator: @Nebulae Nebulae
item.description:
@Nebulae wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:7, topic:460011”][quote author=Nebulae link=topic=562921.msg4103707#msg4103707 date=1347765772]
Even if I managed to stay in school I still wouldn’t of learned something like this. I guess they’ve upped the curriculum a bit since my days.
[/quote]

I don’t think basic algebra is ‘upped curriculum’, but I guess it also depends on when you’re being taught algebra.[/quote]
Well, we never had anything like this when I was at school. I never learned what a term number was or meant.

Read full topic

item.title: Math algebra shit
item.dc:creator: @goudont goudont
item.description:
@goudont wrote:

[quote=“xxx123xxx, post:2, topic:460011”]Well by the distributive property

6 + 4(n -1) = 2 + 4n
6 + 4n -4 = 2 + 4n
2 + 4n = 2 + 4n

since both expressions are the same (they yield the same result), either one of them can be used to find the perimeter of a string of hexagons.[/quote]

thanks man, lil sis needed help and I had no idea wtf this was ahaha

Read full topic

item.title: Math algebra shit
item.dc:creator: @xxx123xxx xxx123xxx
item.description:
@xxx123xxx wrote:

Well by the distributive property

6 + 4(n -1) = 2 + 4n
6 + 4n -4 = 2 + 4n
2 + 4n = 2 + 4n

since both expressions are the same (they yield the same result), either one of them can be used to find the perimeter of a string of hexagons.

Read full topic
